title: AMP trials automated advice
text:
Industry sources say the purpose is to reduce the price point for customers and broaden the demographic reach of AMP's advice network. Bloomberg by Sarah Thompson Anthony Macdonald Jake Mitchell Australia's largest employer of financial planners AMP is dipping its toe into a new form of advice, with a series of virtual hubs being trialled by the institution.
Street Talk understands five or six hubs, which see the client input their financial information into a program for a tailored assessment, have been set up as part of the experiment.
Industry sources say the purpose is to reduce the price point for customers and broaden the demographic reach of AMP's advice network.
AMP isn't the first big institution to look at new ways of delivering financial advice, with ANZ using IBM's Watson system to match clients with a financial plan using a pool of collected data . Clients were first able to use the program more than a year after ANZ first paired up with IBM. It followed a period of "intense training", the bank's global wealth chief executive, Joyce Phillips, said post-launch.
ANZ has also hinted it's investigating other forms of automated and computerised advice to make wealth planning more affordable.
